deliberation: Considered whether the prophetic formula 'the word that came to Jeremiah from YHWH' is purely literal. The collocation treats a verbal message as something that 'comes' like an object or messenger, which reflects a conventional metaphor/idiom for revelation rather than a strictly literal description.

instances.hebrew_text: הַדָּבָר אֲשֶׁר הָיָה אֶל־יִרְמְיָהוּ מֵאֵת יְהוָה
instances.english_text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD
vehicle: a concrete 'word' that can 'come' to someone
physical object or messenger in motion
ground: transfer of a message from sender to receiver
movement from origin to destination parallels reception of speech
communication as transmission
posture: formal prophetic report formula marking authority
instances.explanation: The revelation is conceptualized as a 'word' that physically 'comes' to Jeremiah, using the metaphor of a moving object or messenger to describe an auditory/mental event. This has become a conventional prophetic idiom.

deliberation: The verse commands Jeremiah to write specific spoken words in a scroll. The language of speaking, writing, and scrolls is straightforwardly literal within the prophetic context; no clear metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom beyond normal usage is present.

Examined 'days are coming' and 'restore the fortunes/turn the captivity'. The former is a normal temporal idiom. The Hebrew 'וְשַׁבְתִּי אֶת־שְׁבוּת' is a fixed idiom literally 'turn the captivity', broadly used for restoring fortunes; it functions metonymically/idiomatically for comprehensive restoration.

instances.english_text: when I will restore the fortunes of My people Israel and Judah
target: the overall condition and well-being of Israel and Judah
vehicle: their 'captivity' or exiled state being 'turned back'
reversal of a state of bondage
ground: a complete reversal from loss and bondage to freedom and prosperity
turning around a dire situation
change from negative to positive condition
instances.explanation: The idiom 'turn the captivity/restore the fortunes' uses 'captivity' metonymically for the whole distressed condition of the people and expresses restoration as its reversal.

deliberation: Merely introduces that these are the words YHWH spoke concerning Israel and Judah. No metaphor, simile, or other figurative device beyond literal reference to divine speech.

Considered whether 'voice of trembling' is figurative. It can be understood literally as the sound of panicked cries from trembling people. 'Fear and not peace' is a direct contrast, not a figurative pairing like a merism. Overall the language can be read straightforwardly.
The verse clearly uses a simile comparing men in terror to a woman in labor, and a vivid image of all faces turning pale/greenish to express fear. Both qualify as distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: Why then do I see every man with his hands on his loins like a woman in labor?
target: the men of the nation under judgment
vehicle: a woman in labor clutching her loins
ground: intense, inescapable pain and helplessness
physical contortion and groaning
extreme distress
posture: dramatic warning about the severity of coming trouble
instances.explanation: Men facing judgment are explicitly compared to a woman in labor to convey the extremity and inevitability of their anguish.

instances.english_text: and all faces turned pale [greenish]
target: the emotional and psychological state of the people
ground: visible symptoms of inner terror and weakness
loss of strength and vitality
fear manifesting in the body
posture: vivid description to impress the horror of the situation
instances.explanation: The turning of all faces to a sickly pale/green color is a figurative way of portraying the people’s overwhelming fear and debilitation.

deliberation: This verse calls the day 'great, none like it' (an emphatic exaggeration) and speaks of 'Jacob' as the one in trouble, using the ancestor's name for the nation; that is a standard metonymic/synecdochic usage.

instances.english_text: that day is awesome; there is none like it
target: the coming time of judgment and deliverance
vehicle: a day that is utterly unique, with no comparable day
ground: the unparalleled intensity of the coming trouble
its exceptional severity and significance
maximum seriousness
posture: heightened emphasis on the uniqueness of the event
instances.explanation: Saying that there is 'none like it' is a hyperbolic way of stressing the extraordinary character of the coming day of trouble.

instances.english_text: It is a time of trouble for Jacob
ground: Jacob as representative head of his descendants
using the forefather’s name for the nation
synecdoche/metonymy of part for whole
posture: covenantal and historical framing of the nation’s experience
instances.explanation: The name 'Jacob' stands for the whole nation descended from him, a synecdochic/metonymic way of speaking about Israel.

deliberation: The verse speaks of breaking a 'yoke' from the neck and snapping 'bonds'. These are conventional metaphors for liberation from political oppression, not descriptions of literal farm implements or shackles on Israel's neck.

instances.english_text: I will break the yoke from off your neck
vehicle: a yoke resting on an animal’s neck
ground: external control that restricts freedom and forces service
weight and constraint imposed on the subject
subjection to another’s will
posture: promise of decisive liberation from oppressive rule
instances.explanation: Oppressive foreign rule is portrayed as a heavy yoke on the neck that God will break, using agrarian imagery for political servitude.

instances.english_text: and I will rip off your bonds
target: the constraints of enslavement and captivity
ground: being tied up and unable to move freely
loss of autonomy under compulsion
restriction of action
posture: depiction of God as the one who frees from restraints
instances.explanation: The imagery of snapping bonds continues the metaphor of Israel as bound captives whom God will physically unbind to set free.

deliberation: The key figurative element is the idiom 'raise up' a king, which goes beyond literal vertical movement to mean appointing or establishing a ruler.

instances.english_text: David, the king whom I will raise up for them
target: the future establishment of a Davidic ruler
vehicle: lifting a person to a higher position
ground: being exalted from a low to a high position
installation into a role of prominence
transition from ordinary to royal status
instances.explanation: To 'raise up' David as king uses the metaphor of physical elevation to describe God’s act of appointing or installing a ruler.

deliberation: Looked for metaphors beyond the covenant title 'my servant' and the ancestry-based name 'Jacob'. The most notable figure is the use of 'Jacob' (and parallel 'Israel') as synecdoche/metonymy for the nation, framed in covenant language.

instances.english_text: My servant Jacob … O Israel
ground: the ancestor embodies and represents his descendants
one person’s name stands for the whole people
synecdoche of forefather for nation
posture: intimate covenantal address tying present people to their ancestor
instances.explanation: Calling the nation 'my servant Jacob' and 'Israel' uses the ancestor’s name as a synecdoche/metonymy for the whole covenant people.

deliberation: Considered whether 'make a full end' and 'chastise you in measure' are figurative. In this context, they are standard ways of describing judgment and discipline without a distinct concrete image (like storm, wound, or yoke), so I treat them as conventional legal/judicial language rather than marked figurative imagery.
The verse uses medical/injury language ('fracture', 'wound') for Judah’s national calamity. This is a clear metaphorical portrayal of political/spiritual disaster as bodily injury.

instances.english_text: Your injury is incurable, your wound severe
target: the desperate national condition of Judah/Israel
vehicle: an incurable fracture and grievous wound
ground: severity and apparent hopelessness of the condition
helplessness and pain associated with a grave wound
need for healing/restoration
posture: underscoring the extremity of judgment under human means
instances.explanation: National calamity is portrayed as a bodily fracture and wound that is humanly incurable, setting up God’s later promise to heal.

deliberation: The verse extends the prior medical metaphor, combining legal ('pleads your case') and medical ('for bandage', 'healing') language to describe the lack of remedy for the nation’s condition.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵין־דָּן דִּינֵךְ לְמָזוֹר רְפֻאוֹת תְּעָלָה אֵין לָךְ
instances.english_text: No one pleads for the healing of your sickness, there is no remedy, no recovery for you
target: Israel’s broken covenant and political devastation
vehicle: a sick person needing bandaging and medical treatment with no advocate or remedy
ground: absence of any effective help or advocate
hopelessness of the condition apart from divine intervention
need for both just advocacy and healing care
posture: highlighting the hopelessness of human help
rhetorical deepening of the sickness imagery
instances.explanation: The nation’s desperate situation is depicted as a sickness requiring bandaging and healing, yet with no doctor or advocate to secure treatment.

deliberation: Two main figures appear: (1) 'lovers' forgetting the addressee, portraying political allies/idols as forsaking lovers, and (2) God striking with 'the blow of an enemy' and 'cruel chastisement', continuing the punishment-as-beating metaphor.

instances.english_text: All your lovers have forgotten you; they do not seek you out
target: Judah’s political allies and idolatrous partners
vehicle: lovers who forget and no longer seek their beloved
ground: former intimacy and dependence now betrayed
abandonment by those once courted and trusted
unfaithfulness and rejection
posture: exposing Judah’s misplaced trust and unfaithfulness
ironic reversal of former illicit 'love' alliances
instances.explanation: Judah’s foreign allies and idolatries are depicted as 'lovers' who have now forgotten and abandoned her, using marital/adulterous imagery for political and religious alliances.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי מַכַּת אוֹיֵב הִכִּיתִיךְ מוּסַר אַכְזָרִי
instances.english_text: For I have struck you as an enemy strikes, with cruel chastisement
target: the judgments God has brought on Judah
vehicle: an enemy delivering a harsh physical blow and cruel beating
ground: severity and pain of the inflicted judgment
experience comparable to being beaten by an enemy
sense of hostility and harsh correction
posture: emphasizing the severity of divine discipline
interpretive framing of calamity as punitive
instances.explanation: God’s disciplinary judgment is portrayed in terms of an enemy’s grievous blow and cruel beating, extending the metaphor of bodily punishment for national sin.

deliberation: Reiterates the 'fracture' and 'pain' imagery from vv. 12–14, again using bodily injury as a metaphor for Judah’s dire condition and suffering.

instances.english_text: Why cry out over your injury, that your wound is incurable?
target: the consequences of Judah’s great iniquity
vehicle: a grievous fracture and incurable pain
ground: severity and ongoing nature of the suffering
apparent hopelessness of relief
relationship between cause (sin) and painful effect
posture: rebuking complaint about judgment while underscoring its just cause
instances.explanation: The nation’s suffering under judgment is again represented as an incurable fracture and intense pain, extending the metaphor of bodily injury.

deliberation: The opening clause uses eating imagery ('all who devour you shall be devoured'), a standard metaphor for hostile exploitation or destruction. The plundering language can be taken literally for wartime spoils, but the 'eating' phrase is particularly figurative.

instances.english_text: Therefore, all who wanted to devour you shall be devoured
target: the hostile actions of Israel’s enemies against her
oppression and exploitation of the nation
ground: complete consumption and destruction of the victim
predatory taking of resources and life
one-sided benefit at the expense of another
posture: retributive justice that mirrors the enemies’ own actions
instances.explanation: Those who exploited and destroyed Israel are portrayed as predators who 'devour' her; God promises that they themselves will be 'devoured' in return.

deliberation: The verse explicitly reverses the earlier sickness/wound imagery: God will 'bring healing' and 'heal your wounds'. This continues the medical metaphor for national restoration.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי אַעֲלֶה אֲרֻכָה לָךְ וּמִמַּכּוֹתַיִךְ אֶרְפָּאֵךְ
instances.english_text: But I will bring healing to you and cure you of your wounds
target: Israel’s broken political and spiritual condition
vehicle: medical healing and curing of bodily wounds
recovery of a sick or injured person
ground: transition from damaged, painful state to wholeness
removal of harmful effects and restoration of function
careful, restorative intervention
instances.explanation: God’s restorative work for the nation is depicted as bringing up a healing bandage and curing physical wounds, answering the prior 'incurable' diagnosis.

deliberation: Two figures are prominent: the idiom 'restore the fortunes/turn the captivity' repeated from v.3, and 'Jacob’s tents' as a metonym for the dwellings/people of Israel.

instances.english_text: I will restore the fortunes of Jacob’s tents
target: the overall welfare and status of Jacob’s descendants
vehicle: turning back the captivity/fortunes associated with their tents
reversal of exilic loss affecting dwellings
ground: comprehensive reversal from loss to prosperity and stability
return from exile to secure habitation
undoing previous judgment
instances.explanation: As in v.3, 'restore the fortunes/turn the captivity' is an idiom using 'captivity' as a metonym for the whole distressed condition, expressing its reversal.

instances.english_text: Jacob’s tents
target: the households and dwelling-communities of Israel
the people in their homes and settlements
ground: tents/houses represent the domestic life of the people
dwelling-places stand for their inhabitants
metonymy of place for people
posture: emphasizing care for ordinary domestic life, not just institutions
instances.explanation: The phrase 'Jacob’s tents' uses the dwellings synecdochically for the people and their domestic life, emphasizing restoration at the household level.

deliberation: The line 'I will make them honored [literally, heavy] and they shall not be small' uses the Hebrew root כבד ('be heavy') figuratively for honor/importance, contrasted with being 'small' (insignificant). This reflects a weight-as-honor metaphor.

instances.english_text: I will make them honored, and they shall not be humbled [literally: I will make them heavy and they shall not be small]
target: the future status of the restored people
vehicle: heaviness vs. smallness in physical size or weight
large, weighty body vs. small, slight one
ground: what is heavy/weighty is significant and impressive; what is small is insignificant
social 'weight' equated with honor and influence
contrast between prominence and insignificance
posture: affirming a reversal from humiliation to honor
instances.explanation: The Hebrew verbs use the metaphor of physical weight and size to describe social honor and significance, promising that the people will be 'weighty' (honored) rather than 'small' (insignificant).

deliberation: References to children being 'as of old' and the community being 'established before me' function as temporal and covenantal descriptions. They do not introduce a distinct concrete image used figuratively; they are straightforward in context.

The notable figure is the idiom 'who has pledged/engaged his heart to approach me', which treats the 'heart' as the seat of resolve/courage and speaks of 'engaging' it, a metaphorical way to describe daring commitment.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי מִי הוּא־זֶה עָרַב אֶת־לִבּוֹ לָגֶשֶׁת אֵלַי
instances.english_text: For who would otherwise dare [literally: pledge his heart] to approach Me?
target: the inner resolve and courage of the one who approaches God
human willingness to draw near to the divine
vehicle: putting one’s inner self up as security
ground: total inner commitment and risk in approaching God
the heart as the center of will and courage
binding oneself to an action
posture: stressing the extraordinary privilege and boldness of this ruler’s access
instances.explanation: The phrase 'pledged his heart' uses legal/economic imagery of surety and the heart-as-will metaphor to describe the daring inner commitment required to approach God.

deliberation: This is the classic covenant formula 'You shall be my people, and I will be your God'. Despite its relational depth, it is not built on a concrete image functioning figuratively; rather, it states the covenant relationship directly.

Here divine wrath is vividly imaged as a storm/whirlwind that goes forth and whirls down on the head of the wicked. This is an extended metaphor with personification of the storm as an active agent of YHWH’s anger.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה סַעֲרַת יְהוָה חֵמָה יָצְאָה סַעַר מִתְגּוֹרֵר עַל רֹאשׁ רְשָׁעִים יָחוּל
instances.english_text: Lo, the LORD’s storm goes forth in fury, a raging tempest; it shall whirl down upon the head of the wicked
target: YHWH’s judgment and wrath against the wicked
vehicle: a fierce storm/whirlwind going forth and whirling down
ground: sudden, overwhelming, and uncontrollable destructive force
inescapable impact on those in its path
chaotic yet purposeful devastation
posture: depicting judgment as terrifying and unstoppable
instances.explanation: Divine wrath is portrayed as YHWH’s own storm, a raging whirlwind that falls on the wicked, using storm imagery and personification to convey the power and direction of judgment.

deliberation: The main figure is the personification of 'the anger of the LORD' as something that 'will not turn back' until it has accomplished its purpose, treating divine anger as an active agent that can advance and then retreat.

instances.hebrew_text: לֹא יָשׁוּב חֲרוֹן אַף־יְהוָה עַד־עֲשֹׂתֹו וְעַד־הֲקִימוֹ מְזִמּוֹת לִבּוֹ
instances.english_text: The anger of the LORD shall not turn back till it has fulfilled and completed His purposes
target: the process of God’s judgment being carried out
the effective operation of divine wrath
vehicle: an advancing agent (anger) that can turn back only after finishing a task
ground: persistence of judgment until its goals are complete
purposeful, directed action that does not relent prematurely
anger as a driving force
posture: underscoring the inevitability and completeness of judgment
instances.explanation: YHWH’s anger is personified as a force that advances and only later 'turns back', emphasizing that judgment will run its full course until God’s plans are accomplished.
